text:
Gulf Stream & Currents:
Ocean currents have a direct influence in our lives. They determine our weather, our climate, and much more. The ocean currents and wind systems transport heat from the equator to the poles and operate like a large engine for the global climate.
In the oceans, there are numerous currents. The so-called ocean conveyor belt is very important for our climate. This term describes a combination of currents that result in four of the five global oceans exchanging water with each other. They form a worldwide circulation system.
The conveyor belt is also called the “Thermohaline Circulation”, with thermo referring to the temperature, and “haline” to the salt content of the water. Both determine the density of the water.
While the masses of water may be moved in part by wind, primarily the different densities of the global oceans are responsible for their movement.
Warm water has a lower density and rises.
Cold water sinks.
The water density also increases with a higher sat content.
At the equator the heat from the sun is especially strong, resulting in a lot of evaporation and thus a rise in the water’s salt content. That is where the Gulf Stream begins.
The Gulf Stream is very important for the European climate. Its length of 10,000 km makes it one of the largest and fastest currents on Earth, and it’s very warm.
At roughly 2/m per second it brings up to 100,000,000 m3 of water per second toward Europe.
A constantly blowing wind, the southeast trade wind, drives warm surface water to the northwest, into the Gulf of Mexico, where it heats up to 30ºC.
The turning of the Earth and the west winds then direct the Gulf of Mexico towards Europe and split it up. One part flows south, another east to the Canary Current, and a third part flows north where it releases a lot of heat into the atmosphere as the North Atlantic Current. the water becomes colder there.
Its salt content and density rise on account of evaporation, and it drops down between Greenland, Norway, and Iceland. There we also find the largest waterfall on Earth: the so-called Chimneys, roughly 15-km-wide pillars with water falling up to 4,000 m.   17,000,000 m3 of water per second, or roughly 15 times more water than is carried by all the rivers in the world.
This creates a strong maelstrom, which constantly pulls in new water and is the reason that Gulf Stream moves toward Europe.
Countless species use the Gulf Stream as a means of transport on their trip from the Caribbean to the northern areas. But it doesn’t just bring us animals, an enormous quantity of the warm air also comes with it. In order to produce the same heat that it brings the shores of Europe, we would need 1,000,000 nuclear power plants. That's why we also call the Gulf Stream a heat pump.
Without it, the temperature would be significantly colder here, at least 5 to 10 degrees. Instead of lush fields we would have long winters and sparse ice-covered landscapes in Europe.
In the last few years, scientists and pundits in the media have repeatedly expressed the fear that the Gulf Stream could come to a standstill due to climate change.
Because if the polar caps actually melt, the salt content in water of Greenland would fall, as would its density. The North Atlantic current would no longer be heavy enough, and so it wouldn’t sink as usual. In the worst case, that would bring the Gulf Stream, our heat pump, to a stop.
Some climate experts also assume that climate change could compensate for this effect.
We know that it can be normal for the climate to change by looking at the development of the Earth over the last few million years.
There are ice ages and warm periods:
In the last ice age, a gigantic flood of melting water crippled the heat-bringing North Atlantic Current, covering the Northern Hemisphere in ice.
Scientist have different views of the impacts that climate change will have on the global ocean conveyor belt, but one thing is clear: when climate changes, then the complex system of ocean currents and winds, which has remained fairly stable since the last ice age, will change in ways that we don’t yet understand.

(Oh God, Jesus Christ, etc.) If you have done this, you have violated God’s moral law, you admit that you are a liar, a thief, a blasphemer, and an adulterer at heart. So, if God gave you justice right away, would you be innocent or guilty? Obviously guilty. Heaven or hell? Obviously hell because you are a criminal in God's eyes. Don’t ask for forgiveness, try it in court: Judge, I raped a woman and killed her, but I’m so sorry and I won’t do it again. You would still go to jail because you shouldn’t do it again and you should be sorry. So is there any hope? Yes, there is! Out of love and mercy, God became a human being, Jesus Christ. Jesus lived a sinless life and finally died on the cross to bear the punishment we deserve. His resurrection proved that His death( more accurately, His sacrifical Blood) was enough to pay our penalty, the penalty for our sins. When someone pays your fine, the judge can leave you, dismiss your case, it’s the same with God. Jesus paid our penalty and in order to accept the free gift of salvation from God, we must believe (have faith in Jesus for our salvation, His finished work on the Cross). That's it! God bless you and feel free to ask me any question about this.

text: Something's not adding up in this video.  When it gets to the arctic the salt content increases?  With the melting ice of the arctic shouldn't it decrease? After all the arctic ice is fresh water.  Melt an ice cube into a glass of salt water and the salt water gets diluted (less salty).  Therefore, logically speaking, if there was no melting ice to dilute the water and the planet is now warmer, more water should evaporate and the ocean would become even more salty.  This would in turn make more water sink even faster thus speeding up the global conveyor, not stopping it.  What am I missing?

text:
This is totally wrong!!
The reason NY is colder than Europe at the same latitude has nothing to do with Gulf Stream but with the fact that in the northern hemisphere, the wind blows from West to East and NY is at the Eastern part of the USA which means in winter the air blows from Western USA to Eastern USA and as it does, it cools off and reaches NY much colder than on the Western side of the USA, where temperatures are similar to Western Europe.
Why do you think the coldest winter temperatures are in Eastern Siberia? Its again because the whole Asian continent cools off in winter and the air goes from West to East and when it reaches Eastern Siberia is at its coldest.
Similarly in summer, because the USA warms up, the East part of the USA is warmer than the Western USA.
Gulf Stream does absolutely nothing!  Its a myth !!

text:
You should believe the scientists who have put in the time and effort to understand these, not disbelieve it due to your ignorance.  I you really wanted to know, just research it.  Search engines are at your fingertips. 

In any case, I used to work for the NOAA, and we use many buoys to track several aspects of the ocean at many depths.  Using this information, we can tell where the current is moving and how its properties change from one location to another.  This is just one of many ways we can tell.  We also have satellite observation technology and floating GPS trackers. 

Just google "NOAA How Are Currents Measured" and you will get a very in depth article about how it's done.

text: I love your videos, but would like to make a slight point in this one. The higher salinity in the arctic is not from evaporation. Instead, it is from brine released from aging ice as crystals of more pure water form, particularly when there has been freezing after partial thawing. The  very cold brine can sink rapidly to the bottom. Brinicles are rather extreme and impressive examples.

text: When water from a water/salt solution evaporates, the salt CONCENTRATION goes up, NOT the salt content. The salt content of a meal is, say, 500 mg (sodium), and if you sprinkle salt on top of it, then the salt content of your meal goes up. But if you boil away water from a glass of saltwater or from the ocean using the sun, the salt content remains the same.

text: I love this video!  Already knew a lot about the Gulf Stream, but this is a great visual aid and explanation/teaching tool.  It really illustrates why the Gulf Stream is so important for our climate, in the Northern Hemisphere.   The fact it is connected to the Arctic seawater and currents, as well as now, the melting of Greenland's glaciers, which will inject freshwater into it, diminishing the salt content, is very concerning for our climate future.  Because then, as the video explains, the natural heat pump that has kept Europe warm since the last Ice Age, may shut down. C02 in the atmosphere, from burning fossil fuels, is driving the glaciers to melt (as most people know by now), in both the Arctic and Antarctica. Can't overstate how important our oceans are to maintaining a livable, healthy climate for all living things here on our planet Earth.

If the northern hemisphere is covered in ice, then most of the heat produced at the equator will travel north, so less heat will travel south, and the southern hemisphere will be covered in ice as well.

text:
The oceanic currents are caused by telluric currents in the oceans and/or under the surface. The telluric currents mostly goes along similar paths as what is called the boundery of the so called "tectonic plates" and is the cause behind geological activity found there.
The reason why you can- but most often won't find earth quakes in places where the ocean is at it's deepest is because the telluric currents goes trough the salty ocean water instead of beneath the crust there.
Hawaii is as far as you can get from the so called "ring of fire". So in popular theory you should expect it to be one of the least geologically active places on earth. But if you look at the map of the oceanic currents you will find that hawai exists in the midle of one. This is why you should expect Hawaii to be geologically active.
A nother important factor behind geological activity is when the current have to go back or forth between different media. When ever a current is experiencing a change, like a change in voltage, current dencity or temperature, a so called "double layer" will ocure. The double layers becomes a transitional boundery between plasma (or a medium that behaves like a plasma) of different properties. This results in the transiton from one property to a nother to become abrupt or step like, instead of having a smooth transition like in a gas.
The double layers is what they sound like. They are two sheats of denser charged plasma, that are parralel and very close to one and another. One of the sheets will be negativly charged and one will be possitivly charged. But the most important property here is that they tend to be unstable. So rappid changes, like a sudden increas or decreas in current, can cause the double layers to explode. This is the cause behind earth quakes.
So you should expect these double layers form when the currents exist in shallower water and near the sea shore. Because there you will find the currents to transition between a conductive charged molten rock media and a salty water media. It is in shallow water near the sea shore which you will find the most of the geological activity.
You should allso expect to find them to form when the currents go trough places where the altitude changes. When the altitude changes you will find a change in current density and a reduction in resistance of the currents that goes trough the molten rock under the crust. Which is why you will find mountainous terain to be geologically active, due to the sporadic formation of double layers.

text:
@Diaz Julian

Winds charged with water moderate climates. Warmer air can carry more water than colder air, and when the warm air comes from the sea, it will effectively be charged with a lot of water because of the evaporation caused by sunlight on the ocean.

Water moderate climates because water carries heat and clouds block sunlight.

In your example, London is strongly influenced by warm sea winds, which is why it has cool winter and mild to warm summer.

New York is more lightly influenced by the Gulf Stream because of the winds directions and because of the polar winds that affect it in winter.

Extreme examples of lack of influences by the sea winds are inland areas like Yukon, which have extreme seasons. The winds that should affect it are blocked by the Rocky Mountains (and this is why Vancouver has such a soft climate). London’s climate is oceanic, while Yukon’s climate is continental.

Global warming is terrifying to me. Personally, I avoid behaviors that contribute to the horrifying and rising CO2 levels whenever possible.

text:
Not really. Climate always changes.  Even if humanity never evolved its inevitable that the earth will see hot phases and ice ages again in the future.

author: GhostInTheShell29

text: The current phase of climate shift we're seeing is directly related to human activity. There is plenty of documentation to show that researchers at major oil and gas manufacturers have known about the impending effects of this human-driven climate change long before it was talked about outside of the academic sphere. There was a conscious decision made at all levels of corporate power to ignore the warnings and continue operating under the same business model. Climate change denial is a major part of that strategy. There is no denial at the levels of decision-making, corporate OR government. There are only those who have chosen to help themselves and those who are trying to avert catastrophe. Passing this off as an inevitable natural occurrence wipes our hands of the responsibility to act in the minds of the general public and doesn't even come close to addressing how truly inhospitable we are making the planet to all forms of life.
author: lumburgapalooza

text: @GhostInTheShell29  ._. so you are basically saying that our "problem" would always happen, so its not a global problem?
author: slanspiders

text:
@slanspiders 
It is our problem just like its been a problem for every species ever since live evolved on this planet.

Its not a new problem, you either change your environment or you adapt.

People have such short memories, humanity has had to deal with major climate change multiple times throughout history.  Several ice ages, warm periods.  Much of Africa became uninhabitable after the last super volcano eruption leading to the mass migration across the globe.  Eventually the next one will go off, and humanity will have to adapt again, luckily we have much better technology, and knowledge.

People think just because the last 8K years has been the most stable in history that the earth was always this way.. It wasn't, and it isn't going to stay like this.
author: GhostInTheShell29

text: @GhostInTheShell29  isnt it kinda obvious we called it a human made problem? i mean, obviously theres a natural global warming, but we kinda screwed that over
author: slanspiders

text:
@slanspiders  Mother nature can and has screwed with the climate far more then man kind ever has, in far shorter time frames.

There has been 5 degree Celcius shifts in global temperatures just over a few years.

And people are panicking about a potential 1-2 degree increase?  Over the next century?  it just strikes me as foolish and their approach is abysmal it one won't work, and two just makes everyone lives shittier.

And the way this world is going Nuclear winter seems far to plausible to be ignored in which case thank god we put more carbon in the air.
author: GhostInTheShell29

text: @GhostInTheShell29  m its because there are corals underwater absorbing carbon, we pump out so much carbon its killing the ozon layer, no ozon layer = no protection against radiation
author: slanspiders

text:
@slanspiders 
Carbon doesn't hurt the ozone layer.  Your thinking of CFC's.  Many countries have banned or very limited their use.

All plant life on earth depends on Carbon dioxide.  Though we are currently putting out far more then the environment can naturally take in. 

If that's not rectified in the future it eventually will be a big problem.  Though at the moment we are still well within the norms of the planet's history.  I see the most productive solution is to simply increase the biosphere.  This will allow more CO2 to be converted to oxygen and more CO2 to be sequestered, while providing more plant and animal life to sustain human population growth.

text: @GhostInTheShell29  so you are basically saying that all the drama from politics to global warming is total bullcrap?

text:
@slanspiders 
What they are doing is twisting a real problem into something they can use to make money and support their political goals.

While doing nothing to actually solve the problem.

We need to be investing in better infrastructure, and pursuing geo engineering.

Look at New Orleans for example, instead of raising the city above sea level, we just rebuild the city below sea level after it got destroyed...  Thats just pure stupidity.  Its going to be destroyed again.  In the past when a city was destroyed we'd rebuild it above the flood plain.  Or just move it.

text:
The ozone layer isn't shrinking anymore, its actually growing.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozone_layer

People did take that threat seriously, maybe not as quickly as they should, but efforts made from the late 1970's-1990's to at first reduce and eventually ban certain chemicals.  Has already begun to pay off.

author: slanspiders
GhostInTheShell29

text: @GhostInTheShell29  well yes, the ozon layer will fix itself, but we are now destroying it, causing the ocean levels to rise
author: slanspiders

text:
@slanspiders 
Those things aren't connected, and we stopped destroying the ozone layer when we banned CFC's and other chemicals that caused problems with the ozone layer.

I think you need to read less newspapers, and more scientific journals.  You seem to be jumbling around facts a lot.

Don't get me wrong your intentions are good.  But good intentions without proper facts, logic.. don't turn out well.
author: GhostInTheShell29

text: @GhostInTheShell29  but we still have cars that pump out CO2, we have dozens of factories that pump out CO2.
author: slanspiders

text:
@slanspiders 
CO2 isn't an issue with the ozone layer.  It doesn't break down ozone O3 . 

CFC's were the main problem because they would react with ozone, and could reach the stratosphere.  They were replaced with chemicals that either don't react with ozone, or don't reach the stratosphere.

Even the chemicals that don't reach the stratosphere, but can react with ozone are being phased out in favor of chemicals that don't react with ozone at all.  Just to be on the safe side.

text:
Another problem that may be in balance with the Gulf Stream dying is the glaciers on Iceland. These glaciers silence a few vulcanoes with their weight, so the melting glaciers could result in massive eruptions that could change at least the European weather for months, if not longer and/or more extended. If this melting will continue when the Gulf Stream gets weaker is to be seen, but so far the melting rate is (probably) faster than the weakening rate of the Gulf Stream, which was last reported in perspective to a century while we can almost watch the ice melt.
On another note are the Phenomenons of El Niño and La Niña that affect the Humboldt Stream between South America and Australia, with El Niño being the inversion of the current and La Niña the over strengthening of it due to air pressure. Both are becoming more frequent in recent years and can take effect on the weather on a world-wide scale. For examples: The Famine that was part of the reasons for the French Revolution is connected to them while El Niño in particular let two certain Wars with Russia fail miserably due to an induced harsh winter. I am talking about Napoleon and Hitler here, to make it even clearer. Do not underestimate the forces of Nature for Nature is the true Supreme Ruler of the Planet we call home and not us little monkeys that think that we have enslaved it.

text:
@goku gohan  Depends on when you are referring to. If you are talking about, say, back when the dinosaurs where walking around, debating whether they should fund a space program or not, then theres not really much of a difference. As long as life has been around its been more or less the same, which is a few hundred tons worth of space stuff hitting us each day

If you mean WAY back when, before life, back when earth was still a big ball of molten fire, then its because earth wasnt technically a planet then. Part of the definition for a "planet" is to have sufficiently cleared your orbital path of debris, meaning you are the only big thing left in your little corner of space. To get to that state though, you need to actually clear out the debris. That means smashing into everything until not much of anything but you is left. Once we cleared out our orbit, that means theres not much stuff left for us to be running into each day. Not enough to keep the surface of the planet a molten hellscape anyway. And thus we reach the present day, with less impacts each day. Still a lot of them, a few hundred tons worth a day, but compared to the total mass of earth its not much

author: Paul Joshy

text:
Question for a possible topic on climate change:

How does CO2 reflect the radiation back more than other gases or atmospheric effects such as ice particles in the upper atmosphere or influence climate in general?

Over many years I still haven't heard a proper scientific explanation for this. It would be awesome if you explained that effect the way you explain other sciences!

So far I am agnostic regarding CO2 as cause for climate change. There are much more plausible explanations such as El Nino, Earth's orbital change over time, ice particles in high clouds, natural fluctuation over long intervals, ocean currents, etc.

There is a lot of people who show graphs of CO2 in the atmosphere vs. temperatur, but .. Correlation does not equal causation, right?

text:
@Stephan Schuler  I don't think reflect is the best word. I've mistaken it as reflecting incoming sunlight. Maybe scatter would be better because carbon dioxide absorb the outgoing heat from Earth, and releases the energy in all directions. 
My understanding is that carbon dioxide absorbs the infrared emitted from Earth which cause it to vibrate. Carbon Dioxide then releases energy to stop itself from vibrating. 
An observation that scientist made that shows a trend for temperature and carbon dioxide is Venus. The planet Venus is very hot and it has a much higher concentration of carbon dioxide then Earth.

As usual though, the study of Earth's climate is generally more complicated and complex, so there are certainly many factors.
author: Emile

text:
@Stephan Schuler  CO2 is actually a minor greenhouse gas compared to water vapor and methane.  But, the way it works is that greenhouse gases like CO2 are opaque to shortwave radiation such as visible light, but absorb longwave radiation.  When a greenhouse molecule absorbs radiation, it increases its energy and thus the heat content of the atmosphere.  


I am with you though in that, although the greenhouse effect is real, there's no evidence for any kind of catastrophic climate change, and effects such as El Nino dominate over CO2 over recent history.

text: I don't think you understand, what I'm saying... according to the evidence, we are well on our way to a climate change that will probably cause millions of people to die due to our burning of fossil fuels, which is causing the acceleration in climate change, We are feeling the effects now with the extreme weather events and with warmer and warmer passing years, we have the ability to scale back the anthropogenic warming to manageable levels and prevent millions from dying of hunger, starvation, extreme weather etc...  Yes the climate changes naturally but over hundreds of thousands of years. The change depends on what's the biggest driving force, and right now, its US, you, me everyone. Because of our actions, we are experiencing a climate shift in just 400 years.  This is serious, and I wish it were not true, but the overwhelming evidence tells me I'm wrong.  So.... what are we going to do about it?  If you are okay with our species almost or maybe going extinct, I guess there's nothing else to talk about.

text: So, warming planet leads to ice melt.  Ice melt leads to lower salt levels in the polar oceans.  Lower salt levels leads to a much weaker current that brings warm water/air.  Weaker current leads to lower temperatures.  Lower temperatures leads to ice build up.  Ice build up leads to higher salt levels.  Higher salt levels leads to stronger currents.  Stronger currents lead to higher temperatures.  Higher temperatures leads to more ice melt.  And so on.

text:
Ice floats because ice it's less dense than water, and so floats on top of it. The reason it's less dense is because of its bonding.

--       --    <----- Lone pairs
   \     /
     O    <-----Oxygen
   /     \
Hd+   Hd+  <-----Hydrogen

That (badly drawn) diagram represents the structure of a water (H2O) molecule. The central oxygen atom draws each of the hydrogen's electrons closer to itself, leaving a positively charged nucleus (the centre of an atom).

The oxygen is left with 4 electrons by themselves, which aren't bonded to anything. These split into two pairs of electrons, called "lone pairs", which repel the hydrogen atoms away to the other side of the molecule. This means that on one side of the molecule it's negatively charged (from the lone pairs), and on the other it's positively charged (from the hydrogen).

The hydrogen in other water molecules is attracted to these lone pairs, and vice versa. In frozen water, the molecules are locked in place, so large gaps are left between them due to the X-like shape of the water molecules.

    X
X     X
    X

It doesn't look exactly like that, but it's a reasonable approximation.

In liquid water the molecules can slide past each other, so there are less gaps between molecules, and so it's denser.

Cold water is slightly different. Hot water moves around a lot, so there are slightly larger gaps between warm water molecules than in cold water molecules, making them less dense.

"And the temperature didn't rise anything compared to the predictions they made based on Co2."

That's because the predictions are for roughly the year 2100 and quite frankly we are in 2013 (besides the fact that temperature has risen every year globally since those predictions were made and are "on track" for our CO2 scenario (since there are a few scenarios) ).

"If you look the correlation between Co2 and temperature for much longer periods of time, they are not so in sync. Where as if you look at the correlation between sunspot activity and the temperature is much more accurate."

That's because the changing variable that allows CO2 and the rest of our atmosphere to do its "work" is Solar output, not sunspot activity. Solar output is not expected to significantly change in 100 - 500 years, CO2 ppm is. That's why the focus is on CO2.

text:
No, the Sun's total solar radiance hasn't changed in thousands of thousands of years. We know this because of the nuclear model of main sequence stars.

During solar minimum and maximums, our Sun's output goes max 1368 W/M^2 to 1366 W/M^2. Millions of years ago our Sun was only 70% as bright as we see it now (which is why millions of years ago when its output was lower, we have seen higher concentrations of water vapor and CO2 (2400ppm to 9000ppm), which act in their capacity to warm the planet via radiative forcing.

When we had our "mini ice age", our atmospheric CO2 ppm was roughly 200ppm and the solar output dropped farther out of its standard deviation, decreasing total radiance per meter squared. It should also be noted that the mini ice age was independently regional, not global, as atmospheric compositional data and records kept in countries not in the Northern Hemisphere show.
author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr 
As you noted, solar radiance has been measured by satellites to vary more than predicted by mere theory, about .1% over the last 11 year solar cycle. And that's just for the shortest cycle we currently know about and limited to electromagnetic output as currently measured. Longer cycles show greater variance, also noted by you.

"Knowledge" based on theory tends to give way to actual observations.

A really big example was the discovery in 2010 that rates of decay of particles is correlated with increased and decreased solar activity. The difference was measured with particles here on earth, when lab results from different locations and times were not matching up, however, the variations did link with sunspot activity. (Anyone who has studied quantum mechanics should be really, really surprised by this result, btw.)

So now we should explore new theories regarding variance in fields and changes in the heat radiation from the Earth's core and even volcanic activity which could be correlated with variations in solar activity.

Let's all remind ourselves that climate is an extremely complex topic, still a very young science, and that one day future scientists will be laughing at what we once believed.

My problem is that they are enforcing the ecological actions on the working class, while their money making machines are just sliding by same as before, the problem is that there is so much lie in deception in this world.
author: XtrAMassivE

text:
haha holy shit, do you think scientists that make near minimum wage are trying to dupe you with something you can go out and test yourself? Get real man.

Antarctic sea ice is increasing, you're right, but overall the total amount of ice lost from the Antarctic has not recovered (this includes both land and sea ice. Land ice is not seasonal, sea ice is).

"More and more things are coming out that are contradicting the global warming, climate change is happening in the entire solar system not just here"

Climate systems on other planets do not contradict the findings that humans are significantly and negatively contributing to altering Earth's climate.

Here's how I and other people know you don't have a clue what you're talking about:

Without the Sun, there would be no climate systems on any planet. No shit, congrats on passing 3rd grade physical science.

Now here's what scientists are saying: they are saying that the reason that our climate is changing rapidly because we humans are altering our atmosphere that without industrialization would have never occurred on the scale that has been observed, while keeping natural emitters the same.

Our atmosphere is the reason WE have a climate. By burning hydrocarbons and deforesting the planet, we are changing how our atmosphere behaves because we've changed the chemical makeup OF the atmosphere.

Solar output has not significantly dropped in wattage per square meter, yet our planet is continuing to get warmer (warmer being that the global planet temperature is increasing and the thermal energy contained in our oceans is increasing).

If the planet was warming at the rate it was and humans were not putting greenhouse gasses into the atmosphere, then you'd have an actual plausible hypothesis that we aren't doing anything.

Sadly, the facts contradict that.

author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr  Yes of course that is my one and soul reason.. not
The reason I disagree  with it is that i looked into it and discovered there is much more to the earths climate. I mean, when I first saw the Al Gores movie it had a big impact on me but then after a while informations about  scientific inaccuracies he used to prove his point started coming out i decided to dig further. It became obvious that there are thousands of scientist that don't agree with global warming theory but didn't got any recognition or media attention.

Global warming is political agenda, organization IPCC (set up by UN) exists only because of it and so they are funded with millions of dollars, not to mention other environmental agencies or institutions. What do ordinary humans have to gain? Absolutely nothing, more to loose due to the extra taxes. Yes humans are huge contributors to the local climate and the environment, but the entire earths climate is extremely complex system and only Co2 are not responsible for everything that reflects it. Btw, did you know that animal industry allegedly produces more greenhouse gases (Co2 and metan) than humans do?

Did you check any of the links i give in few comments above? It shows that the correlation with suns activity and temperatures are much more precise than co2 relation. Other thing about data is that it's easy to manipulate it so that it shows what you need to show. If you look Co2 and temperatures on a larger scale it's not so accurate and also now the Co2  and temperatures comparison has deviated significantly since Co2 increased hugely but the temperatures didn't. Why did they even rename it from global warming to climate change if global warming is "settled"?  Pretty much EVERY projection for global warming failed massively, the ice caps will melt... Oh really? They are doing much better than they predicted.

author: The Sapien
bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr  That's because you're an old frost giant. Luckily, it's not about what you want.

Long, long ago, there was a time before oxygen was produced by lifeforms on Earth. When plants started to produce oxygen as a waste, the oxygen caused a Mass Extinction event over the whole planet. Oxygen is extremely toxic in many ways for it being so reactive, even still causes constant oxidation requiring anti-oxidants in lifeforms breathing it today. Now, many animals, like us, use oxygen and trade out giving up more complex compounds that are carbon based which then go to feed plants and algae. So our waste is actually fuel and food for a green planet. Bonus for the plants and algae, too, if the "greenhouse" gasses do actually help warm the greenhouse.
author: The Sapien

text:
@The Sapien 
 Uh, greenhouse gasses are the reason our atmosphere behaves the way it does.

You seem to be lacking a basic understanding of physics.

Yes, some carbon waste products are captured by plant life and used as a catalyst to facilitate their biological function, but here's the kicker:

Before industrialization, there was no shortage of it. Organisms become fit to their environment, and when your environment rapidly changes, they die off because they haven't evolved fast enough to become fit to it.

Current lifeforms are pretty finicky for the most part with regards to how they live in their environment, so no, CO2 is not necessarily and simplistically "plant food".

Perhaps a cursory review of some scientific literature is required: http://www.nature.com/nclimate/journal/v1/n1/full/nclimate1043.html , for example.
author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr 
lol, quite the contrary, I did well in physics. Nothing I've said should had given you the wrong impression about my background in the basic sciences. Physics, chemistry, astronomy, calculus, statistics, etc were all classes I took in college and did well in.

That study you linked to is interesting fodder. Their results did seem to rely mainly on whether or not crops got the water they needed, yet they took more care trying to determine local temps and less care checking what is harder to check (such as water supply). One challenge could be that the authors demonstrated that lack of water is more important than a single degree change. But any farmer could had just told them that and saved on the cost of the study.

So you would believe that farmers do better in colder weather? Well, at least you wouldn't need to irrigate a frozen land. But, seriously, why believe such crazy notions anyway? Such a wacky belief will require far more than weak studies like the above. Might require more crazy pills.
author: The Sapien

text:
@The Sapien 
 There are various plant species that have a wide variety of temperature zones to have bountiful yields, your strawman to turn cooler into frozen is duly noted, since it appears you can't actually support your position with observed science.

This can also hilariously be seen when you take a cursory study and pretend it's the end all be all and instead of like regular science just another set of data for which we use to understand the world.

The world is warming, and humans are helping to accelerate the phenomena. We don't need to know 100% of how physics operates in order to understand that burning hydrocarbons at a rate that exceed carbon sinks contributes to a warmer planet.

We're still waiting for the evidence that people who think AGW is false to be presented. I wouldn't hold my breath though.
author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr  A better scientist remains critical. You're thinking more like a religious defender and not a skeptical empiricist. Don't be so biased, nor hold any post modern theory so close to be cherished. That's the end of science. To progress, remember that your beliefs today must give way to new beliefs tomorrow.

Also, normally, the "burden of proof", so to speak, is on supporters of a belief, not the critical thinkers and healthy skeptics who say that your beliefs are not justified by the evidence.

Personally, I was once a true believer, too. This is one of those examples I remind myself of how wrong I can be even when being so sure. Have you ever been very wrong about something you believed as an adult to learn later that you were so wrong? It makes you far more humble and far more skeptical and a much better scientist.

Back to specifics, you're arguing that plants have a temp zone but then saying it only harms plants to go warmer. Well, by that simple reasoning, going cooler should also harm the plants. Any stray from the ideal would be bad. If this simple reasoning were all that is, it would mean that the farmers in your example area already farming on land that is too warm for what they intend to grow and should switch to another plant or suffer hardships every year no matter. Transposed to the globe, you're saying that the ideal temp of the planet is already too warm, lol. I'm saying that overall, looking at spreads and averages for the entire surface area of the planet, going warmer would mean more regions of ideal temps for various species, not less. Farmers could shift their growing further from the equator while supplanting produce more ideal for any region. Basically, I'm saying we'd have more surface area that could be farmed.

Seriously, greenhouses are good. But now there's like this contradictory, oxymoronic green religion that is actually anti-green and sees greenhouses as evil!
author: The Sapien

text:
@The Sapien 
 Are you really this dense with your sophomoric logic?

Yes, there are a multitude of plants that live and have different yield outputs for temperature zones. Yes, for some of these plants, getting warmer harms them. Yes, for some of these plants, getting cooler harms them. You're not introducing anything revolutionary in science by understanding basic shit.

"A better scientist remains critical."

YES, no duh, but there is no point continuing to go back and recheck stuff that has been constantly re-checked and re-verified.

What has been reverified multiple times: The planet is warming. Humans are emitting greenhouse gasses in concentrations that outpace natural sinks. Solar output has not significantly changed, even during maxima and minima periods, and various other things. This stuff is all available in publicly available research papers that you or I can at any moment go out and test ourselves.

For some plants, crop yields can increase, but this can be negatively impacted as more droughts and other severe weather events that become a new normal afflict crop output.

"Also, normally, the "burden of proof", so to speak, is on supporters of a belief, not the critical thinkers and healthy skeptics who say that your beliefs are not justified by the evidence."

That's what scientists have been doing. You do realize the "skeptics" are in the minority right? Your burden of proof is to support your claim that the preponderance of evidence that other scientists have collected is wrong (which you haven't even done, you're basically simplifying "greenhouse gasses are good!" and then not even supporting it).

"To progress, remember that your beliefs today must give way to new beliefs tomorrow."

No shit, but you're implying that tomorrow we're suddenly going to find evidence that goes against all the observations that the planet is warming.

Good god, how stupid can you be to even think that? The new evidence is for the refined explanation of the phenomena, not the exact opposite.

You've got some stuff to learn chump.
author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr 
Truth is not a democracy. The "majority of scientists" is fine if you're just average and prefer to follow crowds, I suppose. It obviously makes you feel right, at least. Hey, let's do a survey of what Catholic priests believe about the world next to show we can shift the burden of proof on the agnostics!

Not sure you understand what "skeptic" means either. All real scientists ought to be skeptical. It's an absurd false dichotomy to pit "skeptics vs believers" unless we're not really talking about scientists, lol.

As to the rest, same old, same old, nothing new there. Like chatting with a recording. I'll bet you weren't even aware of the connection between solar activity and radioactive decay rates on Earth, as I mentioned above; that why no comment?

@The Sapien 
"Truth is not a democracy. The "majority of scientists" is fine if you're just average and prefer to follow crowds, I suppose."

Someone doesn't understand what a scientific consensus means, it's not how scientists feel, it's where the data points.

Pity. I'm not gonna bother responding to the rest of your ignorant, uninformed dribble, despite your ironic attempts to prove you're educated when really you're not.

Open a fucking book sometime.

author: The Sapien

text:
@The Sapien  Again, with your sophomoric, uninformed attempt at logic.

I'm still waiting for you to prove that:

1. The planet is not warming.
2. Greenhouse gasses do not have any effect on atmospheric temperature.
3. Humans are not contributing anything with regards to changing our planet's climate.

Then I would like you to, since you're so adamant about being a contrarian that can't support their view (I'm still waiting on that, coward), provide your academic credentials that show that you are in fact an expert with regards to this area and why other people should believe you, then provide the research that shows that your position is the more accurate claim and why the current position is wrong in totality (must cite research too).

I'll be waiting, along with the rest of the academic world. I'm not gonna hold my breath.
author: bulletmunchr

text:
@bulletmunchr 
1. I never claimed the planet is not warming. My best guess based on available data is that it likely coming out of an ice age and warming still. On shorter timescales of year to year, it may cool, as it has been a lot, but on scales like decades or more, I would expect to see warming. Fingers crossed. I don't think it's cooling, nor do believe it's at a constant temp since that would be odd in this world.

2. "Greenhouse gasses" is actually incorrect terminology considering that even the consensus agrees on this point. An actual greenhouse works very differently and is not used as a model by anyone. Although, I still kind of like the terminology because green lifeforms love them.

3. Of course humans contribute. No animals live in a bubble.

I am indeed a bit of a contrarian, so much so that I'll often disagree with myself if no one is taking a side against me! (I've actually changed my own mind doing this.) But arguing over who is a contrarian and who prefers pop doesn't really get us anywhere. (I sometimes like pop, too, since dancing to jazz is not so cool.)

Credentials? Always focus on the substance of the ideas and arguments and try to avoid ad hominem attacks. Tho this fallacy seems to be more of a problem for laymen who look up to "experts" as some sort of divine source of knowledge. Avoid such leaps of faith and learn for yourself what is needed to engage in a topic, well, at least for topics which you deem important. Not so important things can be deferred given time restrictions, lol. Fortunately, this is much easier to do today than it was like 20 years ago when I had to go to the library or bookstore for research or had to keep those old textbooks to dust off later; internet is so much better!

Maybe part of why you pegged my stance incorrectly is that you see this issue as black and white and either completely right or completely wrong; as if there were just two sides and everyone was in one camp or the other. As a skeptic, I don't really take sides. For example, I would say that people living in crowded cities do have problems with "pollution" if they don't manage their wastes properly. No animal should live too much in its own waste. But does saying that put me on a side against myself? Only if the world is black and white like Disney.
